abstract_summ: To demonstrate its use and inform urgent decisions as at 30 March 2020, we modelled similar intervention scenarios to those reported by other investigators using various model types, as well as novel scenarios.Although many models have been developed all around the world, transparent models that allow interacting with the assumptions will become more important as we test various strategies for lockdown, testing and social interventions and enable effective policy decisions.The simulated curve for three local areas of Sydney from 1 March to 30 April 2020 was similar to the observed epidemic curve, in terms of peak numbers of cases, total numbers of cases and duration, under a scenario representing the public health measures that were actually enacted, including case isolation and ramp-up of testing and social distancing measures.Our evaluation suggests that ABM models were able to capture the dynamic nature of the epidemic for a longer duration of time while classical SIR and SEIR models performed inefficiently for longer terms.Our team and collaborators are currently developing an extended open-source COVOID package comprising a suite of tools to explore intervention scenarios using several categories of model.
title_summ: Covid-19: analysis of a modified SEIR model, a comparison of different intervention strategies and projections for IndiaMultilevel Integrated Model with a Novel Systems Approach (MIMANSA) for Simulating the Spread of COVID-19COVID-19 Scenarios: an interactive tool to explore the spread and associated morbidity and mortality of SARS-CoV-2Less Wrong COVID-19 Projections With Interactive AssumptionsAnalysis and Prediction of the COVID-19 outbreak in PakistanPoolkeh Finds the Optimal Pooling Strategy for a Population-wide COVID-19 Testing (Israel, UK, and US as Test Cases)Agent-Level Pandemic Simulation (ALPS) for Analyzing Effects of Lockdown MeasuresModel of a Testing-and-Quarantine Strategy to Slow-Down the COVID-19 Outbreak in GuadeloupeCovid-19: analysis of a modified SEIR model, a comparison of different intervention strategies and projections for IndiaMaximising the Benefits of an Acutely Limited Number of COVID-19 TestsContainment of future waves of COVID-19: simulating the impact of different policies and testing capacities for contact tracing, testing, and isolation"COVOID": A flexible, freely available stochastic individual contact model for exploring COVID-19 intervention and control strategies.
title_abstract_phrases: To demonstrate its use and inform urgent decisions as at 30 March 2020, we modelled similar intervention scenarios to those reported by other investigators using various model types, as well as novel scenarios.Although many models have been developed all around the world, transparent models that allow interacting with the assumptions will become more important as we test various strategies for lockdown, testing and social interventions and enable effective policy decisions.Our evaluation suggests that ABM models were able to capture the dynamic nature of the epidemic for a longer duration of time while classical SIR and SEIR models performed inefficiently for longer terms.Our team and collaborators are currently developing an extended open-source COVOID package comprising a suite of tools to explore intervention scenarios using several categories of model.The simulated curve for three local areas of Sydney from 1 March to 30 April 2020 was similar to the observed epidemic curve, in terms of peak numbers of cases, total numbers of cases and duration, under a scenario representing the public health measures that were actually enacted, including case isolation and ramp-up of testing and social distancing measures.
